title: everyone get back to work or rolling in it gets a second series
story: “In which sport will you hear the terms ‘googly’ and ‘full toss’ ”A short silence followed as Gemma quickly dismissed the cricket option and then responded: “I’m going shot put.”A brilliant career switch, I thought, for Gemma who could launch that thing through the ozone layer.But it didn’t really help the celeb civilian dynamic one little bit on ITV’s Rolling In It. A stf of a game show dreamt up by Simon Cowell’s Over The Top Productions company and hosted by Stephen Mulhern, who charged on to the set, Saturday night, shouting: “Oh yes, I hope you’re ready. This is going to be good.”It wasn’t, obviously. It was going to be anything but good.Rolling In It is a show where every single thing is working against it being good, in fact, from the fixtures and fittings to the ropey old format where they’ve attempted to fuse the random “thrill” of Tipping Point with Who Wants To Be A Millionaire , minus the decent cash prize.The technology here isn’t exactly state of the art either. It’s an old arcade game. So, before answering  lobotomised questions , the contestants must roll a gigantic coin down a chute which can end up in a cash prize basket, but more often than not ends up bankrupting them.The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, as you’ve probably noticed, is currently playing exactly the same game with the British economy and probably thinks Rolling In It is a fantastic idea for a game show.ITV in its heart of hearts, though, clearly does not. How can you tell Because they’ve had to ditch the normal, run-of-the-mill contestants and partner-up some visibly reluctant ITV celebs with X Factor-style “characters” who are meant to ert your attention from the game.Saturday night, we had a live wire called Jana, who announced her arrival by telling Mulhern he’d “lost weight”. “What ”The week before there was another handful by the name of Lesley, who brought proceedings to a temporary halt, at the introductions’ stage, with this announcement. “I arrange funerals.”I’d stick around then, Lesley. I’ve checked this show’s vital signs and I think we’re talking weeks rather than months.I worry, too, about the long-term prospects of ITV in the current climate.The share price is down, advertising’s hit an all-time low, Ant  Dec are wintering in Rhyl and the new home for I’m A Celeb is literally a folly.The very remote possibility exists, I will admit, that Rolling In It is part of a deep-state plan to frighten everyone back to work — “Return to the office NOW, or you’re getting a second series of this rubbish.”But I don’t think we really need to look beyond the obvious lockdown explanation here.The cupboard is bare.ITV has simply run out of anything  worth showing, we’re now on to the stuff that was never meant to see the light of day, and as good as it’s ever going to get for Rolling In It is Gemma Collins revealing that: “My intuition is telling me shot put.”Then please go with your intuition, Gemma. Team GB demands it.Nasser Hussein: “The three non-negotiable players were Atherton, Stewart, Thorpe and Gough.”Paul Merson: “Every City signing is just another cog in the jigsaw.”Steven Gerrard: “The quality on the bench is the quality that’s not even on the bench.” BBC’S re-run of the original and arguably best Line Of Duty series concluded, last night, with the Organised Crime Gang still on the loose and DCI Tony Gates putting his tortured Irish wolfhound out of its misery before killing himself.The character I always feel sorry for, watching this  version of the show, though, is Jackie Laverty, Gates’ miserable girlfriend, who had her throat slit in the second episode.She was then stashed in Terry’s freezer, just behind the crispy pancakes and Cornettos, until her corpse was dramatically rediscovered in the fourth episode of the fth series, in April , looking almost as gormless as DI Buckells.In the process, she missed: The show’s big move to Belfast, in series two, the DI Denton years, with Keeley Hawes, balaclava man, Thandie Newton’s appearance, Ted Hastings’ long, dark nights of the soul at the Edge Park hotel, and DS Steve Arnott’s subtle transition from grey tank tops to lurid waistcoats, straight after he slept with DC Georgia Trotman at the beginning of the second run.I’d imagine Jackie actress Gina McKee casts a frosty stare or two in the direction of her agent as well.Line Of Duty may never have been so gloriously easy to understand, or free from abbreviations, as it was in series one, but while her character’s been solidying at Terry’s gaff it has become the most consistently brilliant drama of the decade.Sadly for her, Jackie Laverty is not actually due to defrost fully until series seven and the next runis going to be the last.No official word yet as to when that production will reach our screens but, you can guarantee already, Line Of Duty’s final episodes will be the television event of the year.BBC’s new sitcom Mandy  Well I came and I watched without laughing. So I sent you away. Oh Mandy . . . ITV offering political poison-dripper Tom Watson the chance to reinvent himself as a reality show contestant on Rock The Boat. BBC grovelling before the corpse of that murdering old monster Fidel Castro.This Morning failing to pixelate deeply distressing images of Matthew Wright.Sarky Sporting Nation host Jack Whitehall claiming: “Scotland’s produced some exceptional footballers, Law, Dalglish . . . Robert Snodgrass,” asSnoddy hadn’t run the show when we pumped Malta - away, in .And the words: “You’re exclusively invited to Gemma Collins’ Love Lounge,” actually being uttered by a BBC continuity announcer, who can “exclusively” shove that invite up his Gunga. This is meant to be the BBC not ITV.Guess the identity of Ranvir Singh’s mystery celebrity on Martin and Roman Kemp’s Sunday Best show. “I once kissed one of the most famous sixtysomethings on the planet . . . ” Uhuh. “He was famous for children’s television and . . . ” CUUUUUTITV’S The Le and Times of Captain Sir Tom provided a welcome break from the almost constant diet of molly-coddling and repeats we’ve come to expect in lockdown, last Wednesday.An opinion that would, I think, be shared by the man himself who’s waited the best part of a century to tell his story and certainly isn’t wasting the opportunity now it’s come.It’s one of the things I like about him.Another is the heavy hint he keeps dropping that Burma wasn’t the only ‘action’ he saw in the war.There were “weekends in Bombay,” with a woman called Sylvia, which was: “Quite a happy little thing.”As historian Dominic Sandbrook explained, though, the reason Captain Sir Tom’s revered by the nation is not just the sense he’s the physical embodiment of loved ones we all mourn but their values as well.Public duty, personal sacrice and a sense of proportion that’s been completely lost by those subsequent generations whose capacity for self-pity is matched only by their ability to over-dramatise everything.As Captain Sir Tom demonstrated so perfectly when he dedicated just three words to the years he spent being shot at by the Japanese in the jungles of the far east during World War Two.“It was unpleasant.”We forget them at our peril.INCIDENTALLY, a number of you were angry I didn’t supply the correct answer to last week’s Edna Everage Chase question: “The title of which Dane’s autobiography is usually translated as The Fairytale Of My Le.”But it was, of course, Dane Bowers.I think.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In  Prince Charles became the Duke of which English county ” Amanda: “Wales.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What unit of power is abbreviated to HP ” Jack: “Houses of Parliament.”And Ben Shephard: “In the  West End adaptation of Richard III, which British actor played the title role ” Stuart: “Laurence Olivier.”.This Morning, Eamonn Holmes to chef: “Lamb is something I’m not always favourable towards.” Hates the wool, loves the chops.Rolling In It, Gemma Collins: “I really hope you win. I’ll be so happy for the rest of my le.”This Morning, Gok Wan to Rochelle Humes and Alison Hammond: “I have to say, I’m having the best time today, girls. I’m loving it.”And Celebrity MasterChef winner Riyadh Khalaf: “I’ve literally cancelled everything  in my le. Social le, work . . . ” So, just your social le then GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the triumphs of ronnie osullivan chris woakes and liverpool were just as memorable without fans
story: I’ll leave it to the philosophers among you to unpick that one, but as far as sport is concerned I’ve realised we’re managing very well in the time of the closed doors. In fact, I wonderin some ways we’ve ever had it so good.In football, the Leeds, West Brom and Fulham fans among us have the precious memories of heart-stopping promotion moments to cherish for ever.Similarly, while Liverpool fans would have preferred to have partied with their team, none of them will ever forget the evening Cha did them a favour and the title was theirs. And the intensity of Watford and Bournemouth fans’ misery at relegation will have been no less keenly felt without them being present.In fact, let’s be honest, under the circumstances they might well have been far better off at home anyway.Whether we were there or not turns out not to have mattered quite as much as we thought it would.Watching at home, we even got used to the crowd noise sound-effects. They seemed like the daftest idea ever at first, but so skilfully was it done that I was quite at home with it by the end of the season.I’ve loved the cricket too. I can’t tell you how much I normally enjoy being there for these matches, they’re the greatest joy of the sporting summer. Hordes of inebriated, sunburnt fans howling on their teams, whether I’m one of them, or watching at home, are all part of it. But watching the West Indies and Pakistan Test series unfold even without the mayhem of the crowds has been wonderful.Will, for example, Chris Woakes’ performance in the first Pakistan Test live any less long in our fondest memories for having been played out behind closed doors  Will Chris himself be any less delighted with it  Will his grandchildren care as he rocks them on his knee and tells them about his four fabulous days at Old Trafford in the weird summer of  Actually, you could forgive Chris for not being desperate to have crowds coming back. He played out of his skin behind closed doors in Manchester, and saw his football team, Aston Villa, save themselves from relegation in another deserted stadium days earlier.As for the snooker, pandemic or not, spectators in or out or a bit of both, we were still captivated.As it happens, I watched the Fulham v Brentford play-off final, and some of the snooker, in a sports bar in a hotel in Dubrovnik, Croatia, while an absolutely apocalyptic electric storm raged outside. I sat there with a handful of other Brits, riveted to the screens even as the roof of the place proved unequal to the task of keeping out the rain. What I can only describe as a waterfall soon started cascading into the middle of this bar. And yet we watched on, intently, as teams of Croatian hotel staff rushed around us with mops, buckets and a big kind of water Hoover thing. Nothing could tear us away. Even when something fused and it all went dark, we just filed on to the terrace and watched the storm with one eye, while with the other we watched data from the snooker and football flash up on our phones. Pandemics, floods and whatever  — bring on the plague of locusts — nothing, but nothing, can stop the sport getting to us, and us getting engaged with the sport.And nothing, ever, can stop Ronnie O’Sullivan being Ronnie. First he said the players were being treated like lab rats, then he said a lot of his fellow lab rats were hopeless snooker players anyway. And then he goes and wins the thing. You can’t keep a good bad mad man down, can you Why has sport still managed to grab us by the scruff of our necks in these troubled times  I think there are three reasons: Firstly, we missed it so much when it wasn’t there at all. We loved it before, but we really didn’t know how much until it was completely taken away for us.Secondly, without the crowds, though they are missed, what we’ve been left with is the naked, untrammelled intensity of sporting endeavour. There’s no noise and fervour in the stadia to detract from the purity of the contest.And thirdly, most importantly, the bond between sport and us, between those who play it and those who watch it, is so strong that nothing, but nothing, can ever break it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: divide rich poor pupils passing gcses back to school
story: A devastating report from experts at charity Teach First reveals that in  — before the pandemic hit — just  per cent of disadvantaged kids passed their maths and English GCSEs compared to  per cent of their richer classmates.Even more worryingly, the report shows NO progress was made in closing the attainment gap between disadvantaged and non-disadvantaged pupils in the three years between  and .And unfortunately, thanks to the grim year we’ve had, that gap now looks set to widen.Rich families with easy access to online learning resources took the transition from school to “home learning” in their stride, while in poorer households — where laptops aren’t two a penny — both children and parents had a tough time making it work.Boris Johnson once stood on the steps of Downing Street and vowed to “unleash Britain’s potential” by “levelling up across the country”.To follow through on that promise, he and his ministers must stand up to the bullying unions and insist that ALL our children get the education they deserve this year.As mum-of-two Molly Kingsley puts it on Page Nine: “We can’t undo what has happened. But we can do everything possible to ensure our kids never miss a lesson again.”THE Chinese government’s horric treatment of Hong Kongers and Uighur Muslims violates every human rights law in the book.So we’re pleased that British ministers and royals are plotting to snub the rogue state by boycotting the  Winter Olympics.We know it’s just a gesture. But it’s an important one. When Britain refused to send dignitaries to Russia for the  World Cup, it galvanised our allies to stand up to Putin’s bullying.Two years on, the world is finally waking up to the menace that is China.And we’re proud that once again, Britain is leading the way.NEWS that deaths involving Covid have dropped to a level not seen since March is cause for cautious celebration.It’s proof that we really are over the worst of the virus — and that it’s safe for Brits to come out of hibernation.At the height of the pandemic, we rightly stayed at home to protect the NHS and save lives.Now, it’s our civic duty to protect the economy and save livelihoods by going back to work, to school and to the shops.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dan wootton coronavirus excuse lazy caution kids school
story: WHEN the current madness, hysteria and fear eventually fades, we will collectively look back at the moment on March  when the Government indefinitely closed schools as one of the biggest errors of the coronavirus crisis.Our education institutions never needed to be shut down.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThere wasn’t a scrap of evidence to suggest that shutting schools was necessary to stop the march of Covid-.In fact, study after study from overseas soon proved unequivocally that the spread of the virus at schools was minimal,not non-existent. I can excuse the caution of Boris Johnson and Gavin Williamson deciding it was better to be safe than sorry in the early days of an unknown pandemic.But as the weeks turned into months and Generation Corona effectively lost a school year, I will never forgive the militant teaching unions for keeping them shut regardless of the social cost.It was a partisan play designed to damage a Tory government at a time when politics should not have mattered one iota.Unfortunately, the A-levels mess this week was depressingly inevitable from the moment the school gates slammed shut.A knee-jerk decision to cancel all exams without waiting to seethere was a way they could be sat in a socially distanced manner meant the current crisis was unavoidable.This situation CANNOT ever be repeated — but I’m fearful it’s already happening.Coronavirus is now being used as an excuse not to provide anything slightly dficult or complicated in all areas of our lives.But when it comes to education, the costs of that lazy caution are too great.I don’t know about you, but much of the development I experienced at school was down to my social interactions and extracurricular activities, rather than solely what was taught on the blackboard.Yet many schools are intending to use Covid- to justy axing breakfast and after-school clubs, banning music lessons and school productions, and stopping sports.It breaks my heart to see these opportunities indefinitely wrested from our youngsters with no scientic evidence to back up why.But it is being caused by a desire from adults to avoid ato normality.A King’s College London study this week revealed a majority of the public are supportive of our nightmarish “new normal”, with  per cent believing employees should be able to keep working at home until a vaccine is discovered and administered.This is cloud cuckoo land thinking. While the progress in Russia and at Oxford University looks positive, there is no guarantee we are going to have a vaccine at all.  So here’s an unpleasant newsflash: Covid is going to be part of our lives for many years. After all, smallpox is the only infectious disease to ever have been eradicated.Selfish adults can ruin their own lives by giving in to irrational hysteria, but they shouldn’t be allowed to destroy the fair education of our kids.The fightback against militant education unions, box-ticking bureaucrats and cruel social distancing regulations for students must begin today.MUCH media attention this past week has been focused on Labour MP Dawn Butler’s dubious claim that London cops are institutionally racist because they pulled over her and a black mate, even though they were driving in a vehicle with tinted windows, meaning the officers had NO IDEA of their colour.What’s far more disturbing is the release of new figures showing violent assaults on Met officers have increased by  per cent in the past three months, coinciding with a period of social unrest sparked by coronavirus and Black Lives Matter protests.Our police are under attack from all angles.They are filmed by baying members of the public desperate to show discrimination but unable to release their own body cam footage.They are accused of racism simply for arresting criminals.Andwe’re not careful, they will give up trying to stop many crimes because the potential repercussions aren’t worth it.DISTURBING news for celebrity lovers: The stars you probably think are nice are usually utter horrors in real le and those with bad reputations publicly are often delightful off camera.That’s my experience after two decades reporting on the entertainment industry both here and in Hollywood.So I’m fascinated to see a celebrity not being nice is now an offence that can see them be “cancelled”, becausethat goes on, there won’t be many left on the telly.This week, in one of the biggest celebrity reporting injustices I’ve ever seen, Nadia Sawalha was hit by claims she is nasty behind the scenes.Believe me, I saw it all over ten years working at ITV Daytime, but can vouch that the Loose Women star is one of the kindest and most genuine people I have ever met in the toxic world of showbiz.To suggest she is some sort of fake is beyond the pale.Nadia is adored by everyone backstage, her best friend is one of the broadcaster’s make-up artists, and she cares deeply about the folk she works with.While some TV stars don’t know the names of crew members they’ve worked with for years, Nadia befriends most of them.The vulnerable, self-deprecating, caring and honest-to-a-fault list you see on Loose is the real woman I know and adore.FIRST the US broadcaster HBO axed Gone With The Wind, before introducing a title: britain bouncing back coronavirus lockdown businesses high street
story: The first official statistics detailing thefrom lockdown reveal High Street and shopping centre activity is picking up.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd traffic is almost back to normal levels — with  per cent of White Van Men back on the road.Experts and MPs have welcomed statistics showing that more people are getting out and about and boosting business after the Covid- crisis.The figures show nine in ten drivers have ed to the road and millions of shoppers are back on the High Street.But many office staff are failing to get back to work — which is affecting city centres.PM Boris Johnson looked at the positives and hailed the “hugely encouraging” signs. The Office for National Statistics data showed footfall at all retail locations is up to  per cent from a low of around ten per cent in early April.Shopping centres and High Streets are back to  per cent of last years levels of visitors.Ninety-three per cent of businesses are back open. Seventy-seven per cent of firms said there was no risk or a low risk they could go bust.Goods vehicles are once again clocking up their usual mileage. And overall road traffic is just nine per cent lower than before lockdown.Tonight, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: “It’s great to see people back out and about, using our roads to boost business and drive our economic recovery.Sun readers will be happy to see that we’re setting out plans to spend £billion on improving our roads — reducing congestion, pollution and journey times. And we aim to cut through red tape and get projects done faster.”But while many drivers are getting back on the roads, commuters are still shunning trains and buses.Train passenger numbers are only at  per cent of last year’s levels. And bus usage is at just  per cent of what it was.In London, where millions of office staff are still working from home, Tube passenger numbers are  per cent the level of last year. The capital’s buses are only  per cent full.A third said lockdown had not aff­ected their turnover for this year. But half said they had seen a decrease.Just one in eight of the workforce remains on furlough.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s Eat Out to Help Out Scheme to boost restaurants, cafes and pubs was used  million times last week. Data up to Monday of this week showed road traffic just nine per cent lower than the equivalent Monday in February. Britain’s White Van drivers are back to  per cent of pre-Covid- rates.ONS senior statistician Chloe Gibbs said: “Road traffic data shows the number of car journeys is ing to normal levels as people venture out to shops and travel to work.”But many huge firms are still telling workers to stay home and it is having a major knock-on effect on rail, Tube and bus commuter numbers and the wider urban economy.It is a huge blow for cities like London, Birmingham and Manchester. Their centres became ghost towns during lockdown.Cafe chains including Pret a Manger have announced job cuts as a result of having fewer customers.Rail usage has slumped to  per cent of last year’s levels, the Tube at  per cent and buses at  per cent.NEWS that Britain is bouncing back to normality is music to our ears.Last month, behavioural scientists worried that nervous Brits might let the economy tank rather than come out of hibernation. But they underestimated our resilience: High streets up and down the country are bustling once again . . . and ever-dependable White Van Man is back out on the road.We caution, though, against getting lulled into a  sense of security.New ONS data reveals that a whopping  per cent of employees are STILL on furlough, proving the extent to which the job retention scheme continues to prop up the economy.As the scheme tapers off, it’s inevitable that thousands of hardworking and blameless employees will be let go.We’re concerned too about the future of offices — and the cleaners, shop owners and transport workers who depend on their survival for work.On the Continent, the vast majority of city workers are back behind desks. But in the UK, business districts are ghosttowns as white collar employees find they like the work-from-home lestyle.It would be churlish not to celebrate today’s good news. But celebration must be tempered with pragmatism: The scarring effects of lockdown will be felt for months,not years, to come.For a full recovery, we must all make a concerted effort to shore up the economy by going out to work, pubs and the shops.  Tonight Tory grandee Iain Duncan Smith warned: “Office workers, civil servants, those in big companies are really being shown up by the self-employed and small businesses who are all getting back to work and are thus helping the economy.“Its down to these businesses and their office workers to recognise their responsibility, and get back to the office so they can help all the smaller businesses, the cafes, restaurants and bars in the centre of our towns and cities, so they are able to prosper again.”A No spokesman said: “This data shows our economy and society have reopened successfully — and it is hugely encouraging this has happened without a resurgence in the virus.”WE all faced tough times during lockdown and only when it was right did Prime Minister Boris Johnson give the green light for our shops to reopen.But customers have stayed away in droves, leaving the retail landscape looking like a series of ghost towns.Figures from the Office for National Statistics estimate that around , people in England currently have the coronavirus — less than . per cent of a population of around million.And while our neighbours in Europe have flocked backed to their offices, we’ve been more wary over here.Around  per cent of French white-collar workers are back at their desks,  per cent of Italians and  per cent of Germans.Here, it is just  per cent.That has a knock-on for those city centre businesses that rely on those workers for trade, such as sandwich shops and dry cleaners. Not forgetting trains and buses that ferry workers around.Already the job losses are piling up, with Marks  Spencer announcing it is shedding , staff over the next three months.I fear it could get a lot worse with many more thousands of jobs lost across the High Street.Pre-Covid, there was the hustle and bustle of happy shoppers thronging the stores while office workers were spending in their breaks.It breaks my heart to know that shoppers are staying away in their millions and thousands of staff are losing their jobs, with countless businesses being brought to their knees.But it’s not just down to the public, we need action right from the very top of government.People need to have their confidence boosted, and while everyone appreciates we are in unprecedented times and it is tough, it is also the responsibility of the Government to show the way back, just like our counterparts have done in EuropeWe need support for entrepreneurs with low rents in new or abandoned units. And councils could use their compulsory purchase powers to turn empty buildings into places where businesses can thrive once more with good, safe public transport.Add to that safe cycling, rent “holidays” and flexible-term agreements to help get businesses back on their feet.So come on shoppers, shop and office workers, let’s get our High Streets and city centres buzzing again.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: joe biden us election radical left
story: The veteran Democrat and former Vice-President almost crashed out just after the long race for the White House had officially begun. In the Iowa caucuses, the first electoral contest of the campaign to become his party’s candidate, the -year old finished in a humiliating fth place. “I’m not going to sugarcoat it. We took a gut punch,” Biden declared after the disastrous result. One commentator on the news outlet CNBC was even more scathing: “His presidential hopes are finished.”Yet today, Biden stands on the threshold of the Oval Office. Victory is in his grasp. Having clawed his way back into the primaries and won the Democratic nomination to challenge Donald Trump, he could soon be the most powerful man on Earth. It is certainly his fight to lose. Some nationwide opinion polls put him no less than  points ahead of Trump, whose popularity has taken a battering because of the coronavirus crisis and the consequent economic recession. This week’s Democratic convention, including his own powerful, well-crafted speech last night, will have done nothing to undermine his lead.But with some worrying signs of mental decline, Bidens coronation could mean the reigns of power are actually handed to the hardline leftists around him - rather than to the ageing politician himself.What makes Biden’s comeback all the more remarkable is that his two previous attempts to reach the White House failed so miserably. In  his campaign fell apart after he was exposed plagiarising one of the speeches made by Neil Kinnock during the British General Election the previous year. Some of the passages were lted almost word for word. “Why am I the first Kinnock in a thousand generations to be able to go to university ” asked the Labour Leader.“Why is Joe Biden the first in his family ever to go to university ” asked the Democratic Senator. It does not say much for either Biden’s creativity or his judgement that he had to seek secret inspiration from a socialist mediocrity widely known at Westminster as the Welsh Windbag.In  Biden did even worse, dropping out after a woeful performance in the Iowa Caucuses, where he gained just one per cent of the total vote. During the campaign, he regularly put his foot in his mouth, most notoriously when he described his rival Barack Obama as “the first African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice looking guy”.This year, after Iowa, his chances seemed to be heading in the same sorry direction.But then, in the following months, he gradually emerged as the front-runner. This was mainly because the other leading candidates were seen as either too extreme or too unlikeable. Senator Elizabeth Warren was a hard advocate of toxic identity politics who unconvincingly claimed to have Native American blood. Bernie Sanders was North America’s answer to Jeremy Corbyn, complete with revolutionary economics and brutish tax plans. Peter Buttigieg was a sanctimonious mayor of a small city in Indiana, without any experience of the national stage.In contrast, Biden had not only been a Delaware senator for  years, but had also served as Vice-President throughout Obama’s time in the White House. Through these roles, he had built up a reputation as a moderate, helped by his image as an ordinary, down-to-earth guy rather than a member of the Washington elite.The son of a used car salesman, he was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania, the place where the US version of Ricky Gervais’s comedy The Office was set. His popular appeal was further enhanced by his personal story of having to cope with agonising grief, which he spelt out in raw, emotive terms last night.The catalogue of anguish includes the loss of his first we and daughter, killed in a car accident in  and the death of his son Beau from brain cancer in . Yet none of this can hide a disturbing reality about Biden, one that makes him profoundly unsuited to be the leader of the free world or the commander-in-chief of the US military.It is something that the Democrats have desperately tried to downplay, along with much of the media. But, the fact is that Joe Biden is in steep mental decline. Already by far the oldest Presidential candidate in history, he shows all the signs of advancing senility. He might be able to read effective from an autocue, as he showed last night, but in other settings, away from the podium, he regularly stumbles over his words, confuses facts, loses his train of thought, and lapses into coherence. His supporters say that he has always been “gaffe-prone” and that is true, but the problem goes much deeper. In the past, Biden could be sharp, even witty, as he showed in his triumphant  Vice-Presidential debate against the Republican Paul Ryan.Today, when speaking off the cuff, he struggles to string basic sentences together.Without the help of a teleprompter, this is a man who mixes up his we and sister, gets the names of countries wrong, and keeps repeating the same phrases. In one bizarre outburst in Iowa, he called a female reporter “a lying, dog-faced pony soldier”. In another contribution, he declared that he will “choose truth over facts”. With a delusional grasp of arithmetic, he has said that million women will be put back to work by his tax credit plan, that million Americans have been killed by guns since , and that million have died from Covid-. That is why, throughout the campaign, his minders have tried to keep him in his Delaware home, almost like a hostage. Major interviews have been banned, public appearances strictly rationed. It is a strategy that his team cynically justy by claiming that they want to protect the -year-old candidate from Covid-. But the determination to shield the potential next President from any accountability makes a mockery of democracy.It might seem bizarre that the Democratic party should march under the tattered standard of such a weakened general. But from the viewpoint of political operators on the left, his decline actually makes him an ideal candidate.His senility might have to be concealed from the public, but it can be ruthlessly exploited in private. Broken and bewildered, Biden is a puppet whose strings can easily be pulled by his hidden masters. Behind the thin veneer of his supposed moderation, the radicals can seize power and enact their hardline policies, like defunding the police, imposing financial reparations for slavery, rewriting American history, confiscating wealth, promoting transgender ideology, extending public ownership, and widening the scope of affirmative action. Precisely because he is now an empty vessel, a Biden Presidency would mean the ruthless enforcement of woke dogma. In fact, its unlikely that he will last a full four-year term. Therefore his Vice President Kamala Harris, an ambitious operator can start preparing for her reign.But perhaps she should not be too hasty. The Democrats’ opportunism could backfire badlyvoters become alienated by the idea of an enfeebled President.After all, the American political structure – in contrast to our Parliamentary system – is built on the concept of a strong executive headed by a powerful, elected head of state. Already Trump, never one to pull his punches, is running adverts that highlight concerns about the “cognitive decline” of “Sleepy Joe”. The commercials seem to be having an impact. Almost  per cent of Americans do not think that Biden will serve a full term, while other polls show the race narrowing. Trump could also be boosted by revulsion at the radical Democrats’ agenda, especially the collusion with urban violence.In  widespread unrest fuelled by the civil rights movement enabled the Republican Richard Nixon to defeat the Democrats under Hubert Humphrey. Famously, Nixon said that the “silent majority”, ignored by the media, had spoken. Today the same public mood could give Trump a second term.It would be no more than the Democrats deserve for their eagerness to hide the real Joe Biden.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: priority poorer students alevels universities
story: Michelle Donelan, the universities minister, has said that kids from disadvantaged backgrounds should be given spots after a record number of kids were given higher A-levels. The Government has scrapped caps on student numbers but many universities are still grappling with finding enough space for the number of kids who met the terms of their offers. Universities admissions body UCAS found that an extra , students now have the grades to get into their first choice uni.Ms Donelan said in a letter to vice-chancellors: “Where possible, try to prioritise those from disadvantaged backgrounds for admission this year.”The failed algorithm for deciding A-level grades was ditched earlier this week in a massive Government U-turn, meaning more students met their university offers. But universities are concerned about litigious middle-class parents who might take up legal actiontheir kids dont get a place and have to take a gap year, according to The Times.Watchdog The Office for Students has backed the move to give priority to poorer school leavers. Chief exec Nicola Dandrige said:“While it is for universities to make inidual admissions decisions, students from disadvantaged backgrounds must not be allowed to slip through the net as admissions decisions are made.”But one admissions head has said universities may not follow the instruction, which does not set out how disadvantaged should be defined. There is a range of criteria normally relied on to decide who is from a deprived background - including those who lived in particular areas or attended schools where fewer people go onto higher education, as well as those from low-income families or ethnic minority backgrounds.The admissions head said: “In hard choices like these they would normally look at GCSE grades or parts of the personal statement. “I fear that many may already feel they have met their targets for disadvantaged children getting into university this year so have done enough.”Head of the Higher Education Policy Institute Nick Hillman, said it was not a simple decision. He said “If I was a vice-chancellor, or running admissions, I would worry that the wording is open to all sorts of challenges, even legal ones.“Do they have sufficiently robust information to make that fine judgment  Is it based on parents’ salaries, or ethnicity, or other characteristics  It is open to interpretation. How do you satisfy this without opening yourself up to potential legal challenges  No one is against giving an extra leg-up to people from very under-represented groups but there are a lot of litigious middle-class families out there and schools are very keen to ensure their progression rates are good this year.”Head of UCAS, Clare Marchant told BBC Radio  it was the right thing to do to prioritise poorer kids who are less likely to be able to take a gap year. She said: “I think it is absolutely the right intention. I think we know from all of our survey work that those from most disadvantaged backgrounds really, really worry about money. And sothey are deferred for a year, or asked to defer for a year, we’re likely to see a drop-off. And so that’s the real intent behind that.She added: “I think what I would say is that universities are very inidual, they make inidual decisions, but all of them, having spoke to a number of them at Universities UK over the course of the last days and weeks, are looking to be as super flexible — they want students to come to them.”The Office for Students is fighting off demands from campaigners that disadvantaged children should be given compensationthey have to take a gap year. Durham University has gone a step further to free up places and tried to convinced students to take a gap year by offering them a bursary.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum harshest parking ticket tyre inch over line
story: Baffled Rebecca Edge has blasted the £ fine as ridiculous, petty and incredibly unfair. title: uk coronavirus r rate above 1 every region england rise
story: Four regions in England have seen a slight increase in the vital measure since last week - while every range is now at or above .⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhen the value is below one, it means transmission of the virus is no longer high.But the reality is the true R rate probably lies somewhere between the upper and lower estimates.Experts warn that as Covid cases are much lower than they were at the peak of the pandemic, the R rate is more sensitive to even small outbreaks.It comes as separate official figures today show that around , people are being infected every day - but new infections have levelled off.Yet hospital admissions remain low - with fewer than  every day - and intensive care staff say they are seeing less Covid- patients in recent weeks.Medics today suggested it could be because more young people are being infected while those most vulnerable to the virus have already died.It comes as: The latest figures published today by the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesshows that the rate has increased across the country as a whole.Last week, the UKs R rate was in a range between . to ., but thats now up to . to ..The North West, South West, London and South East have also seen slight increases in their R rates.In the North West, where a number of places have been forced into tougher restrictions, the R value range has increased from . - . last week to . - . today.R, or R nought, refers to the average number of people that one infected person can expect to pass the coronavirus on to.Scientists use it to predict how far and how fast a disease will spread - and the number can also inform policy decisions about how to contain an outbreak.For example,a virus has an R of three, it means that every sick person will pass the disease on to three other peopleno containment measures are introduced.Its also worth pointing out that the R is a measure of how infectious a disease is, but not how deadlyLondons range went up from . - . last week to . - . today, while the South West also went above the crucial value and is now at . - ..The South Easts R rate range was just below  last week - at . - ., but Sage say this has now nudged up to . - ..But Government advisers say that the latest growth rate shows that the epidemic is somewhere between shrinking by three per cent and growing by one per cent every day. This measurement reflects how quickly the number of infections are changing day-by-day.It is an approximation of the change of number of infections each day, according to Government experts.  If the growth rate is greater than zero , then the disease will grow, but less than zero then the disease will shrink.But the experts say that the figures lag a few weeks behind the countrys current situation because the Government uses a iety of data sources.A Sage spokesperson said: We have been seeing indications that these values may be increasing, with estimated ranges increasing slightly from previous publications. Recent changes in transmission are not yet fully reflected in these estimates because the data used to calculate R and growth rate reflect the situation from a few weeks ago. It is also important to recognise that these are estimates, and there is a high degree of uncertainty with them. They added: For this reason, Sage does not have confidence that R is currently below  in England. We would expect to see this change in transmission reflected in the R and growth rate published over the next few weeks as we gain more certainty of what is currently happening.Meanwhile, experts have issued caution over the accuracy of the R rate estimate when cases are so few.Prof Keith Neal said that local Covid clusters can also push the R rate up for an entire region when it may just be one small area.The epidemiologist at the University of Nottingham said: “Making estimates of R with small number of cases becomes increasingly dficult and inaccurate.  Hence the wide range of the estimates.It comes as the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics published today suggests that new coronavirus infections have levelled off.An average of , people per day in private households in England were estimated to be newly infected with Covid- between August  and .This is lower than the previous estimate of , new infections per day for the period August  to .However the ONS said there is not yet enough evidence to say for definite that there has been a fall in new infections in the most recent week, and therefore we continue to report that the incidence rate for England has levelled off.A Government spokesperson said: The very slight movement in the R number reinforces the importance for all of us of staying alert to control the virus and save lives.“But the number is an estimate with a high degree of uncertainty due to areas with lower case numbers or iabilities across the UK. It is only one indicator of how the UK is faring – ONS statistics also published today suggest that infections have levelled off.“We are in a far better position to deal with this virus than at the start of the pandemic but to continue to keep us all safe we must remember to wash our hands, cover our faces, keep our distance and get a testwe have symptoms, so that NHS Test and Trace can keep the virus under control.Earlier today, an intensive care specialist said that he is seeing fewer patients needing critical care for Covid-.Dr Ron Daniels, a consultant in the West Midlands, suggested it could be because those who are most vulnerable to the disease have already died, while a spike in Covid cases could be among young people going out more.He told BBC Radio s Today Programme: I think there are considerations around the positivity rates, but were not looking at the case fatality rates and we’re not looking at hospital admissions.Weve seen cases go up since the beginning of July, and still our hospitals are relatively empty of patients with this condition. We’re seeing very few patients admitted to hospital, let alone requiring intensive care.Experts say that the rise in the R rate is to be expected as the country eases out of lockdown - and warn that the virus is still spreading.Dr Yuliya Kyrychko, a mathematician at the University of Sussex, said: “The latest estimates of R number appear to indicate that in all regions of England, the estimates of R number have either remained the same or have grown in the space of one week. Most worrying about this is the possibility that in several regions, including London, South West and North West, the R number exceeds , suggesting a possibility of a substantial growth in new infections in these regions in the near future. With ONS data estimating around , new infections in England and Wales in the week - August, this means that the infection is still very prevalent across all of the UK, hence it is of paramount importance that people continue to follow the guidance on protection and social distancing to prevent major local outbreaks.The list is based on the percentage of the population with symptomatic Covid- from data submitted by more than . million app users in the UK.Here is this weeks full list...These latest figures were based on the data from , swab tests done between August  to August . Dr Michael Head, a senior researcher in global health at the University of Southampton, said: “We are seeing increases in new daily cases, and now we have an R number estimate that is approximately at the . threshold. The data suggests that as people mix more freely, there are probably increases in community transmission. This is to be expected, but highlights the problems in coming out of lockdown, particularly when there are many thousands of active cases in a population.Suppressing COVID- is extremely dficult. We know that most cases are transmitted within the indoor environment.It’s currently August, and so outdoor meetings are possible, but as we head towards the winter, fewer people will be inclined to meet outside. That raises dficult questions about how best to handle social contacts across the winter months, particularly with the increased potential for transmission from younger populations, who usually have relatively mild cases, on to vulnerable populations where the consequences can be more serious.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eviction ban extended another month
story: NewsEviction ban extended for another month in last-minute government u-turnMinisters were warned there could be mass evictions around Christmasthere was no extension to the ban - which was due to expire on MondayShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsHousing Secretary Robert Jenrick " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe ban on evictions has been extended for another month, the Mirror understands, in a last-minute government u-turn.Ministers confirmed the move following warnings from charities and Labour leader Keir Starmer.And when the ban expires, Landlords will be required to provide tenants with six months notice in most cases, meaning no evictions would take effect until at least the end of March .Charities feared there would be mass evictions around Christmasthe Government did not give judges powers to stop automatic evictions of tenants affected by the coronavirus outbreak.Renters have been protected during the crisis by the ban, announced in March and extended in June. It was due to end in England and Wales on Monday. Mr Starmer welcomed the extension, but said it should be extended further.He said: The government’s eleventh hour u-turn on the evictions ban was necessary - but such a brief extension risks offering only short-lived relief to tenants.The ban must not be lted until the Government has a credible plan to ensure that no-one loses their home due to Covid. The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government has now confirmed the four-week extension. But Sir Terence Etherton, Master of the Rolls - Englandaposs second most senior judge - confirmed the extension in a letter this afternoon. He said Justice Secretary Robert Buckland had written to him yesterday to confirm the extension. He wrote: The CPRCmet earlier today. It considered the extremely unusual nature and timing of the letter of direction from the Lord Chancellor but by majority considered that it was bound to follow the direction. He aded: This -week extension to the stay relating to housing possession cases, will allow for further work to be done to prepare for the stay to be lted which in many respects can be welcomed. The Housing Law Practitioners Association also said it had been confirmed to them, tweeting: We have now had official confirmation that the stay on possession proceedings will be extended to  September. Earlier, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps hinted a u-turn was on the cards. He told LBC radio: I know that getting that balance right between the renters and the landlords is something that my colleagues in the housing ministry are working closely on, and I think they will make further announcements about it shortly, which Iaposm not privy to right now.Polly Neate, chief executive of Shelter, said:   “The government has today recognised the very real danger that tens of thousands of renters are in. It is right for the government not to lt the ban when it risks exposing people to eviction and the threat of homelessness with no means of defence. “The government must use this short window of time wisely to put proper safeguards in place for renters. People are still falling behind on their rent – , private tenants since March - leaving them vulnerable when the ban does end. And we all know even more economic storm clouds are gathering. “A bullet may have been dodged with this extension, but as soon as Parliament s, it must give judges extra powers to stop renters being evicted because of ‘Covid-arrears’.   Facing eviction this Christmas, is not a present anybody wants.” But the National Residential Landlords Association did not welcome the news.  Ben Beadle, CEO of the National Residential Landlords Association has said:“A blanket extension is unacceptable, especially so close to the deadline.   “An enormous amount of work as gone into finding a balance between supporting tenants who have been affected by the pandemic and preventing signicant financial harm to landlords, in accordance with the Government’s promise. This announcement satisfies no-one.  “Landlords have been left powerless in exercising their legal right to deal with signicant arrears unrelated to Covid-, antisocial behaviour and extremely disruptive tenants who make le miserable for their neighbours and housemates.   “Private landlords cannot be expected to foot the bill for government failure. There must now be a plan to support households to pay their bills and to compensate landlords fully for their lost income.  “Only this will give both tenants and landlords security and reduce the risk of widespread tenancy failure.”

Many deals were handed out without any competition, under urgent procurement arrangements to react to the pandemic. London-based start up Signal AI was paid almost £, to perform media analysis on the Governmentaposs Covid- communications, while accountancy giant Deloitte was paid £ million for urgent consultancy services. Rachel Reeves, Labouraposs Shadow Cabinet Office Minister said: Spending millions on media work won’t make up for political incompetence or mixed messages from ministers.No amount of spending on public relations will undo the damage Dominic Cummings did by challenging the sense we were all making sacrices together.All too often the Government’s approach to procurement has been shambolic or questionable in its decisions and so we need more robust checks and balances put in place. They were paid £, for an analysis of Government contracts handed out in relation to Covid-. Mr Tugendhat told the Mirror his cousin had no input into the business. He added that the contract had been awarded directly because his firm offered a service the Government needed, and no other company could provide. Some £ million was handed to marketing firm Mullen Lowe infor “Covid- campaign services”.

Lulworth coastguard said the swimmer got into trouble in choppy seas at Durdle Door, Dorset, on Thursday afternoon. The man, believed to be in his s, apparently tried to swim back to the shore but was stopped by mph winds and enormous waves that rose well over his head. Another man who ran into the sea to try and help him also got into dficulty before dozens of people on the beach came to the rescue. More than  people linked arms to enter the sea and successfully brought the two men back to shore. They withstood being buffeted by the waves and an eye-witness said she feared for multiple casualties, but miraculously everyone emerged unscathed. Witness Emily Foote said: The foam was like a washing machine and at one point I thought we were going to end up with  casualties in the sea rather than just one. The whole beach applauded when the two men got back and they didnapost need any help from paramedics or anything like that. Iaposve never seen the beach like that and full credit has to go to everyone who risked their own lives to save the swimmer.  Jeanette Warren, from Portsmouth, Hants, said: He was confidently swimming for some time until an awful gust came and literally swept him so far out. He was actually very good, staying calm and then giving it his all to swim with the waves. A small crowd quickly became a very large crowd and people on land began to realise he was in distress. A statement by Lulworth Coastguard Rescue team said: With the large waves and spring tides of late, we strongly discourage sea swimming and playing around in the surf, especially on exposed beaches such as Durdle Door.

Sharon Goldie claimed Robyn Goldie was attention seeking despite the sick  year-old begging for help as she lay dying of a perforated ulcer. She had earlier been put on the child protection register after Goldie was found to be drunk while supposedly caring for her daughter. This led to the child staying with her gran until  in what was described as a stable le. Robyn then ed to her mum in Wishaw, Lanarkshire, due to a number of reasons including starting secondary school. But, the court heard social workers continued to monitor the pair. Prosecutor Ashley Edwards QC said: Goldie was offered - on ious occasions - the opportunity to attend parenting classes. She declined to attend. Goldieaposs drinking became an issue causing friction with her daughter. Miss Edwards: Goldie asked forto be removed from her care. Social workers visited the pair - often unannounced - with arguing between them described as common. The house was also said to be stinking of cat urine. The court heard how Robyn told a friend she did not like her mum drinking. It was at this time Goldie appeared to be a regular at the Melody Bar in Wishaw. Miss Edwards: Robyn was often seen attending there looking for Goldie and asking for money to buy food. She also often approached a neighbour asking for £ to get food. Robyn once said she had only had a yoghurt that day. The child was described as thin, dirty and unkempt.  Miss Edwards: On an occasion , Goldie was heard to say: aposI am f***ing sick of her. I wish she would go back and stay with her granapos. The court heard Robyn would also film Goldie - who slapped and bit her daughter - screaming at her. The child told friends how drunken Goldie would offer her cannabis and alcohol while constantly insisting she did not want her in the house. In March , Robyn was then found to have a rash caused by fleas. The week before her death, Robyn was given painkillers after complaining of a sore stomach and legs. Goldie pleaded guilty to a charge under the Children and Young Persons Act of wilfully ill-treating and neglecting Robyn, who died after suffering a burst stomach ulcer. The  year-old later found her daughter slumped on the sofa - but left to go out in the garden to have a drink with a friend. It was only after they eventually discovered Robyn was dead that an ambulance was finally called for. On July , Goldie then told staff at the Melody Bar she had locked her daughter in the house so she could not get out. The next day, Robyn complained to a friend she had been ill and not eaten for days. But, on July , Robyn texted her gran claiming she felt a lot better. However, a friend of Goldie saw the drained girl that day and told the mum: Sheaposs just not well. That night, Robyn told Goldie to get help as she had pain all over. Miss Edwards: She refused to contact an ambulance. Another friend of Goldie said he would go instead with Robyn in a taxi to hospital - but stopped him claiming the girl was attention seeking. The next day, Robyn begged a neighbour to get her an ambulance as she could not breathe. But, her mum yelled at her to get in. On July  - the day Robyn passed away - the court heard it is thought likely a stomach ulcer she had burst.

For Jo and her new husband Andy, it had been love at first sight and she admits everything happened really quickly. They moved in together soon after meeting  years ago and within six months Jo was pregnant with Poppy. Then, six years ago, the couple celebrated their dream wedding before jetting off to Alicante on a sun-soaked honeymoon. With them was their little daughter, Poppy, and Joaposs mum, who had come to celebrate and so the happy couple could have some alone time on this special holiday. But just a few days into their honeymoon, on July , Jo was mown down by a drink driver and left with devastating injuries. She and Andrew had gone out for the evening and were walking along a path when a car careered into her, with her new husband uninjured because he was just a few paces behind. Jo, from Wakefield in West Yorkshire, said: I was lying on the path and I thought I was going to die. I thought to myself, aposIaposve got married, Iaposve had my little girl, Iaposm fiishedapos. But then I made a deal with God. I swore I would do anything to survive, no matter what my injuries were. The crash had left the former beautician with a broken spine, four crushed vertebrae, five broken ribs and a cracked sternum. She was rushed to hospital in Spain where medics desperately tried to stabalise the young mum, who should have been on the holiday of a letime but was instead fighting for her le. Jo had to spend four weeks in hospital in Alicante before she was declared safe to travel because of fears about a blood clot close to her heart. She had to be flown home on a stretcher and after initially being treated in her local hospital, she had to be quickly transferred to Leeds General Infirmary because of complications. Jo recalls screaming in pain during her first days back in the country. Finally, after five weeks of hospital treatment, Jo was allowed tohome for the first time - but her le would never be the same again. She had to wear a brace at all times and the room where she had previously carried out beauty treatments was converted into her bedroom - it became her entire world. Unable to get out of the specially adapted bed, Jo had to rely on carers coming in to help her wash, change and even get out of bed four times a day. Beside her at all times was her devoted husband, Andrew, who was forced to give up his job at Warburtons so he could care for his badly injured we.  The driver who had ploughed into her was convicted of causing the accident and jailed for four months and one day. He has now passed away after serving his sentence. Finally on December , , Jo was allowed to take her brace off for the first time and she admits it was a terrying moment. She said: I was so scared because I thought my bones were going to collapse. I didnapost like to move. But the amazing thing was being able to get into the shower after all those months. I could wash my hair for myself and that was amazing, it really was the little things that made all the dference. But Jo also had a gruelling  months of rehab and physio to enable her to go back to something resembling a normal le. And ato her old le was impossible. Jo had been a successful beautician but because of the scale of her injuries, that was no longer possible. The -year-old said: I was working a lot of hours and I had to be fit and healthy to massage people and carry out the treatments, this just wasnapost something I could do after what happened. However, determined nothing would get in the way of her family le, Jo retrained and now works in marketing. Itaposs had the added advantage of enabling her to spend more time with Poppy, now , something she sees as a positive.Andrew, after leaving his job at Warburtons, is now a decorator and works for himself. However, the long-term impact of the crash has not only left Jo with mobility problems, she now also suffers from the debiliating condition, fibromyalgia, which leaves her in almost constant pain. The previously fit and healthy mum has also gained five stone after spending so long immobile and is still unable toto the gym. And, after years of battling to keep the home that she and her family live in and which she bought from her parents aged just , Jo has been forced to make another heartbreaking decision.The five-bedroom house is too much for her and Andrew to manage because of her condition and the family want to downsize. Jo and Andrew have come up with an ingenius plan to sell theyaposre home - and it could be yours for just £. Instead of selling through an estate agent, they are raffling the property, which comes with its own man cave, garden and all itaposs furnishings, which are worth around £,. The house itself has been valued at £,.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother of eight who scrounged almost £, in illegal welfare claims has been spared jail after she offered to enrol on a taxpayer funded programme to help her realise her crimes were not victimless. Saaba Mahmood, , pocketed state benefit handouts on behalf of her aunt and uncle over a five-year period - even though she knew they were living in their native Pakistan. But when she was caught, Mahmood, of Heald Green near Stockport, Greater Manchester, said she did not realise she was unable to claim on the behalf of relatives who lived abroad. She also claimed she lacked skills in understanding how to live in society as a responsible adult and added that she did not realise her offences were not victimless crimes. At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, Mahmood admitted four charges of failing to disclose information to make a gain and one offence of fraud but was given  months jail suspended for  months. Prosecutor Julian Goode said: These are cases relating to benefit claims on behalf of her aunt, uncle, and mother. She acted as an appointee for them and in that capacity and she had a duty to disclose changes in circumstances that would impact the claim. She claimed Disability Living Allowance on behalf of her aunt between January  and September , and Employment Support Allowance between February  and October . She was acting as her auntaposs appointee and as a result both benefits were paid directly into her bank account. There is evidence to show her aunt left the UK in January  to go to her daughteraposs wedding in Pakistan but fell ill there and did notto the UK until  October . The defendant did not disclose this and continued to receive those payments in her behalf between February  and October . These payments totalled £,.. Her uncle claimed Disability Living Allowance between November  and October  and Employment Support Allowance between October  and October . The defendant became his appointee in July . She got the credit into her bank account, but he was out of the country between November  and October  and again between October  and June  and June  and December . The defendant failed to report the change and the overpayment was £,.. The defendant became an appointee for her mother in July  and on  August  she said her mother was able to care for her uncle and received Employment Support Allowance. On  October  she reported the change that her mother had stopped caring for her uncle. The overpayment in this case was £. The total overpayment was £,.. The defendant was interviewed on  February last year and confirmed her aunt had been living in Pakistan between  and . She said she did not know she needed to reportsomeone was abroad. She said she had reported that her uncle was in Pakistan in September . She said she completed forms between June  and November  in which she failed to mention he was in Pakistan. A breach of trust was involved. At an earlier hearing a lawyer for Mahmood said she would benefit from programmes to help her understand these are not victimless offences. They added: She lacks skills in understanding how to live in society as a responsible adult. At Thursdayaposs hearing in mitigation defence lawyer Isobel Thomas said: She is genuinely remorseful and has repeated this on a number of occasions to let the court know how sorry she is. She pleaded guilty at the earliest opportunity. Only one of the claims was fraudulent from the outset and that claim was worth £.  Immediate custody will have a signicant harmful impact on others. She has eight children aged between one and  who have to go into foster care as her husband has schizophrenia and is unable to care for them. Her youngest two children are very close to her and sleep by her. One of her daughters has been assaulted in the past and appeared as a witness at a Leeds Crown Court trial. She is nervous of men and other people. Her husband gets very distressed when she isnapost there and may have to go to hospitalshe were sent to prison. She is a carer for her aunt who has dementia, hepatitis C and kidney failure. She has never troubled the courts before and no longer claims benefits. She would comply with all requirements of a suspended sentence. Mahmood was also ordered to complete  rehabilitation requirement days and  hours of unpaid work.

The couple were spotted arriving at the castle ready for a relaxing countryside break with Eugenieaposs grandparents. Photos shared on social media show them looking happy and relaxed in casual outdoor wear, with Eugenie carrying a large orange box with a black bow. Both the Queen and Prince Philip celebrated birthdays in lockdown, so it may be a late present for their special day. The Monarch spends every summer at Balmoral, and dferent members of the family come to stay over the warmer months. Her youngest son Prince Edward and his family were among the first to visit, and were seen walking around the grounds with the Queen last week. He was joined by we Sophie and kids Louise and James, but there is a change that theyaposve now ed home as Louise picked up her GCSE results yesterday. The Queen and Philip ended months of lockdown in Windsor when they flew to Balmoral at the start of this month, and theyaposre expected to stay there until at least September. They were driven from Windsor to RAF Northolt in London this afternoon, where they then boarded a plane heading to the ,-acre Aberdeenshire estate.  The couple sat side by the side in the car, and the Queen had her trademark black handbag resting on her lap. They are joined in Scotland by whataposs been dubbed their aposBalmoral Bubbleapos, a small team of key staff who will look after them during their stay. It includes master of the household Vice-Admiral Tony Johnstone-Burt, the Queenaposs private secretary Sir Edward Young and Paul Whybrew and William Henderson, her pages. The Queen was living at Buckingham Palace when the pandemic began, but was whisked to Windsor before lockdown was introduced.Speaking at the time, a source said: She is in good health but it was thought best to move her. An outbreak linked to the Greencore Factory, which makes sandwiches for the upmarket retailer, will see staff and members of their households having to isolate for  days. The Department of Health said that local testing data and analysis from the Joint Biosecurity Centre had shown a spike in cases in the area to be almost solely down to the outbreak at the Northampton factory. The site employs , people and initially did not close its operations despite reporting dozens of cases. The department said: The factory will close voluntarily from today and employees and their direct households will be required to isolate at home for two weeks. The Health Secretary will introduce regulations to ensure that this self-isolation period is legally enforced. Anyone who leaves isolation prior to the two-week period ending without reasonable excuse will be subject to fines. The outbreak saw Northampton upgraded to an area of interventionapos due to the spike in infections. While Birmingham has a coronavirus infection rate of . per , people, Northamptonaposs rate is far higher at . as it is a much smaller place. In all intervention areas bar Northampton, possibly because the outbreak is so localised, restrictions have been imposed, while enhanced support zone councils have received more backing and mobile testing units have been dispatched. The Department of Health said Health Secretary Matt Hancock would bring in regulations to ensure that this self-isolation period is legally enforced and warned that anyone who does not abide by the rules without a reasonable excuse could be fined. Director of Public Health Northamptonshire, Lucy Wightman, told the BBC: The factory will close voluntarily. Most employees and their direct households will be required to isolate at home for two weeks.  Northamptonaposs incidence rate has hit . per , people, in the week ending  August. Mrs Wightman said the current situation is fragile in the East Midlands town. She said: If we donapost keep continuing to work together to reduce the transmission of the virus there is a very real possibility that further and stricter intervention measures and a possible local lockdown will follow. A message sent to staff at Greencore, and shared with the BBC, states the company has decided to put all colleagues working at the Northampton siteon a period of  days self-isolation.  It adds: We know this will come as concerning news for all our colleagues. We will therefore send further updates to you on the action you need to take shortly. Please stay safe. A spokesman for Greencore said the company had taken the decision to temporarily cease production at its Northampton facility from the end of today as a result of the ongoing COVID- outbreak in the Northampton area and at the site. This decision will allow all remaining colleagues at the site to self-isolate as a precautionary measure, and has been taken as part of the regionaposs ongoing efforts to reduce the spread of the virus and keep our colleagues safe.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSAS hero Bear Grylls is on a mission to push more women through gruelling Army fitness tests and get them signed up as soldiers. The TV survival legend has agreed to spearhead a new drive to get hundreds more female recruits to become frontline troops in just a few months time. Grylls, , has secretly agreed his organisation British Military Fitness will join up with recruiting giant Capita to improve applicants’ fitness levels. Capita has hit recruitment targets over the past two years, but wants to help the MoD create a more gender-inclusive Army. It follows a high drop off rate in female recruits applying to join up and then either falling short on fitness or not going to basic training for other reasons. As much as  per cent of all candidates signing up to join the Army are females, after new gender inclusion rules now mean women can fight alongside male soldiers. But as many as  per cent of them have fallen slightly short on strict fitness tests which are just as gruelling as those undertaken by male candidates. This comes despite Army commanders noticing that females who do join the Army very often out -perform their male colleagues in toughness. Bear Grylls – joint owner and figurehead of BMF - told the Daily Mirror exclusively: “British Military Fitness has the military expertise, nationwide reach and a community fitness for all philosophy that ideally positions us to support Capita and the Army. “The goal is simple: to improve physical performance and readiness of potential recruits. “Our instructors and members come from a broad range of backgrounds which enables us to provide anyone who wishes to join the Army with the best possible chance of passing the Armyaposs entry standards. “Weaposre hugely proud to be part of this initiative and in collaboration with the Army and Capita we look forward to making a positive impact to our Armed Forces. “Women have proved to be some of the best recruits weaposve had lately in the Army and have proved time and time again to be just as strong as men.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry handed out nappies and helped kids try on school backpacks at a drive-thru charity event near their new LA mansion. The couple wore face masks as they joined other volunteers at charity BabyBaby, which provides basic necessities for families in need. Pictures show the couple handing supplies to people through car windows at Dr Owen Lloyd Knox Elementary School in South LA on Wednesday. Both looked casual, with Meghan wearing loose khaki shorts and a white shirt while Harry opted for brown shorts, a white polo shirt and a baseball cap. A source told Town  Country: “Everyone was in great spirits. The kids were eager to receive their books and supplies and Meghan and Harry did what they do best - engage and connect with the crowd.” Meghan and Harry also chatted to parents and children who looked to see the special royal guests.  The volunteering comes after it emerged the couple have bought a £million mansion in the celebrity hotspot of Santa Barbara. They moved out of movie producer Tyler Perryaposs LA house in July, buying the nine-bed property after taking out a £.m mortgage and getting some financial help from Prince Charles.The couple had been house-hunting for some time after relocating to the US from Canada just before the coronavirus lockdown. Theyaposve settled on Montecito, which is where a number of their celeb pals including Ellen DeGeneres and Oprah live.A source told  PageSix  Harry and Meghan have been quietly living in their new home for around six weeks.This is where they want to continue their lives after leaving the UK. This is the first home either of them has ever owned. It has been a very special time for them as a couple and as a family.  Yesterday Meghan spoke openly about voting ahead of the US presidential election, making a surprise guest appearance at Michelle Obamaaposs When All Women Vote online event. She told fellow American womenyou are complacent, youaposre complicit during her video message, and described voting as being part of a legacy. The former US First Ladyaposs organisation aims to increase participation in elections and to close the race and age voting gap by changing the culture around voting. Speaking from her LA home, Meghan said: We can make a dference in this election and we will make the dference in this election. I think itaposs an exciting day, because it is the countdown to the change that we would all like to see for the better for our country. She went on to say: As we look at things today, though it had taken decades longer for women of colour to get the right to vote, even today we are watching so many women in dferent communities, who are marginalised, still struggling to see that right come to fruition, and that is - itaposs just simply not okay. And we look at the attempts of voter suppression and what thataposs doing, all the more reason we need each of you to be out there supporting each other to understand that this fight is worth fighting and we all have to be out there mobilising to have our voices heard. I think we are obviously faced with a lot of problems in our world right now, both in the physical world and in the digital world, but we can and must do everything we can to ensure all women have their voices heard.
